intro: Pseudopogonatherum contortum var. pedicellatum, commonly known as the twisted false beardgrass, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia and Africa. It is a member of the grass family (Poaceae) and is characterized by its slender, twisted stems and small, spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in open, disturbed habitats such as grasslands and along roadsides. Its leaves are narrow and often have a hairy texture, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense spikes. This species is of interest in botanical studies due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptability.
